Graphical abstract Heteroatomic dual-doped metal free graphene materials have revealed significant improvement in the electrocatalysis properties for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in alkaline anion exchange membrane fuel cells. Here we report a straightforward and cost-effective strategy to fabricate N, S- and N, P- dual-doped reduced graphene oxide electrocatalysts, characterized by similar N/S and N/P ratios. For this purpose, we used ammonium sulfate ((NH4)2SO4) and ammonium monohydrogenphosphate ((NH4)2HPO4) as heteroatom precursors to obtain the desired catalysts by pyrolysis with graphene oxide. Systematic characterization reveals that the secondary heteroatom S has a greater promotional effect than P in ORR. Furthermore, the gap between the onset potentials of N, S- dual-doped graphene and the standard Pt/C is only 30 mV. The results imply that the combination of the N, S heteroatoms and the surface structure in dual-doped reduced graphene oxide lead to a synergistic effect in catalyzing ORR in alkaline media. Keywords Metal-free electrocatalyst Dual-doped graphene Oxygen reduction reaction Fuel cells 1 Introduction Alkaline anion exchange membrane fuel cells have been considered highly efficient and environmentally friendly energy converters in recent decades, and therefore a possible solution to the global energy and ecological problems related to fossil fuels [1–3]. However, the sluggish electrochemical reduction of oxygen at the cathode causes a significant decrease in fuel cell voltage and efficiency impeding the development of this technology [4–6]. The most common active electrocatalysts for ORR are Pt-based precious metals, but they have some drawbacks such as high price, short supply and poor durability [3–5,7–9]. Recently, several heteroatom-doped nanostructured carbon materials, such as graphene, nanotubes and nanofibers, have been developed as metal-free catalysts with impressive electrocatalytic performances for ORR in alkaline media, due to their outstanding excellent mechanical properties and significant conductivity of π-π bonds [7,10–15]. It has been known that heteroatoms with different electronegativity and size such as N, P, S, F, Si and B have a significant effect on the electrochemical properties of graphene. By doping graphene with electron-rich atoms such as nitrogen, a positive charge density redistribution is induced on the adjacent carbon atoms, which facilitates the chemisorption of oxygen and/or ORR intermediate products and charge transfer, resulting in enhanced ORR activity [16–21]. Contrarily, a positive charge is induced on the electron-deficient heteroatoms of doped graphene, such as boron. Such positive charge density also favors the chemisorption of the dioxygen molecule and facilitate the ORR process [22–24]. The similitude of heteroatom-carbon distance with the CC interatomic distance also plays a decisive role in the type of doping that occurs on the graphene network. Accordingly, given the similarity of the B–C and NC interatomic distances to the CC bond length, doping with B or N atoms leads to a graphene-like geometrical structure [11,17,25]. Consequently, the similar bond lengths of CN (1.41 Å) and CC (1.42 Å) causes that pyridinic and graphitic N have a negligible influence on the graphene structure [10]. On the other hand, the interatomic heteroatom-carbon distances of P and S exceed the CC bond by approximately 25 %, leading to an exohedral or distorted structure where the heteroatom can be localized above or below the graphene sheet [26–28]. Dual-doped graphene can create greater flexibility for modulating the electron structure by optimizing the doped locations, the densities of the dopants and their ratios. In most cases, in addition to nitrogen doping, other heteroatoms such as S, B and P are used to regulate the properties of the modified graphene [17,29,30]. Experimental and theoretical studies have demonstrated that the density and location of the co-doping affect the level of ORR activity [31–33]. An enhanced electroactivity is usually attributed to the synergistic effect between dopant atoms. S induces high spin density in carbon atoms, increasing the chemical reactivity to ORR of the N-doped graphene [34–36]. The direct substitution of N and P at high stable doping levels can adjust the graphene's chemical and electronic characteristics, creating more functional groups and modifying the electrochemical efficiency [37,38]. However, despite the promising potentials of simultaneously doped graphene in the energy sector, there have been few reports presented on dual-doped graphene so far. In this work, a straightfoward, cost-effective and controllable strategy was developed to fabricate N/S and N/P dual-doped graphene electrocatalysts. For better comparison, we used ammonium sulfate and ammonium monohydrogenphosphate as precursors for the preparation by pyrolysis with graphene oxide at 800 °C of the desired catalysts with the same N/S and N/P ratios. We investigated the ORR activity in alkaline media and the effect of the secondary heteroatom, S and P, under similar conditions. Moreover, the relations between the doping level and electrochemical ORR performance were also investigated. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and chemicals Graphite powder (99.999 %) of 2–15 μm, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30 %), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 36–38 %), sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 98 %), potassium permanganate (KMnO4, ≥99.0 %), sodium nitrate (NaNO3, ≥99.0 %), ammonium monohydrogenphosphate ((NH4)2HPO4, ≥98 %), ammonium sulfate ((NH4)2SO4, ≥99.0 %) and Nafion solution (5 wt%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. 2.2 Synthesis of dual-doped graphene catalysts Graphene oxide (GO) was synthesized from graphite power by following a modified Hummer’s method [39]. Initially, 2 g of graphite and 92 mL of concentrated sulfuric acid were mixed for 12 h at room temperature. After complete dissolution, 2 g of sodium nitrate were added and the solution was stirred again for half an hour. Then for the oxidation process, 12 g of potassium permanganate were added to the solution which was placed in an ice bath, and stirred for two hours. Immediately after this step, the solution was stirred in an oil bath at 35 C for 24 h. After that, 400 mL of deionized water were added slowly. Then 12 mL of hydrogen peroxide were added to the solution giving rise to a brilliant yellow colored solution. Finally, the solution was washed with a 10 wt.%. Aqueous sodium chloride solution (400 mL) to separate the excess material followed by using deionized water until to reach a neutral solution. The rGO was produced by the reduction of GO with sodium borohydride NaBH4 following standard procedure. The N and S co-doped reduced graphene oxide (NSG) was synthesized by pyrolysis of graphene oxide and ammonium sulfate as N and S precursor. In a typical preparation procedure for catalysts, 1 g of graphene oxide was dispersed into deionized water with a solution of 10.0 mg/mL ammonium sulfate. The ratio of ammonium sulfate:GO was kept at 3:1. Then the slurry was stirred at room temperature for 12 h, and afterward, the concentrated dispersion was completely dried using a freeze drier. After that, the power was transferred into a quartz tube furnace and heated at 800 °C at the rate of 5 °C/min for 2 h in an N2 atmosphere, followed by a cooling procedure at room temperature under N2. The N and P co-doped reduced graphene oxide (NPG) was synthesized by the same procedure, but using diammonium monohydrogenphosphate as the N and P precursor. 2.3 Structural characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a diffractometer with a Cu Kα (λ=0.15405 nm) radiation source (40 kV, 40 mA). For studying the morphology and elements distribution of the samples, the field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, Helios Nanolab 650) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-1400) were used. Micro-Raman spectrometer (JASCO NRS-5100, 532 nm Laser) and the specific surface area (SSA) and pore structure analyzer (Micrometrics, ASAP2020) were used to characterize the composition and structure of samples. The surface area was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and the pore size distribution was determined by using the BJH method. The surface heteroatom content of the samples was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements recorded with a Physical Electronic PHI 5700 spectrometer using non-monochromatic Mg-Kα radiation (300 W, 15 kV, 1253.6 eV). The spectra of powdered samples were registered with a constant pass energy values at 29.35 eV, using a 720 μm diameter circular analysis area. The XPS spectra obtained were analyzed with PHI ACESS ESCA-V6.0 F software and processed using the Multipak 8.2B package. The binding energy values were referenced to C 1s signal (284.8 eV). Shirley type background and Gauss-Lorentz curves were used to determinate the binding energy. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements The electrochemical characterizations of the electrocatalysts were carried out in a three-electrode cell at room temperature controlled by a potentiostat-galvanostat Autolab. For the working electrode, a rotating disk electrode (RDE) with a glassy carbon disk (area = 0.107 cm2) was used. An RHE electrode and a platinum electrode were used as the reference and the counter electrodes, respectively. The catalytic ink was made by the sonication of 4 mg of the catalyst with a solution of Nafion (15 μL), isopropanol (300 mL) and water (700 mL). An aqueous solution of NaOH (0.1 M) was utilized as supporting electrolyte. N2 (99.99 %, Air Liquide) was employed for deoxygenation, and O2 (99.99 %, Air Liquide) was introduced to obtain a saturated solution for the oxygen reduction reaction measurements. Meanwhile, with flowing O2 and at 1600 rpm, the ORR activity was evaluated based on a polarization curve ranging from −0.1.0–1.2 V with a scanning rate of 0.005 Vs−1. The LSV was carried out with four different rotation speeds (ω): 900, 1225, 1600 and 2025 rpm. The number of transferred electrons (n) during the ORR was calculated at various electrode potentials based on the Koutecky-Levich equation [40], according to Eqs. (1) and (2): (1) J−1 = JL −1+ J K −1 = B−1ω-1/2 + J K −1 (2) B = 0.2nFCo Do 2/3 υ−1/6 where J is the measured current density, JK and JL are the kinetic and diffusion-limiting current densities, respectively, ω is the rotation speed (rpm), n is electron transfer number, F is the Faraday's constant (96,485 Cmol−1), Co is the bulk concentration of O2 (1.2 * 10-3 molL−1), Do is the diffusion coefficient of O2 in 0.1 M NaOH (2.22 * 10-5 cm.s−1), and υ is the kinematic viscosity of the electrolyte (0.011 cm2 s−1). 3 Results and discussion The synthetic strategy is illustrated in Scheme 1 . The N,S dual-doped reduced graphene oxide (NSG) was synthesized by pyrolysis of graphene oxide and ammonium sulfate as N and S precursors. Similarly, the N,P dual-doped reduced graphene oxide(NPG) was synthesized using diammonium monohydrogenphosphate as N and P precursor. Fig. 1 shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) profile of NPG and NSG, including XRD profiles of graphene oxide (GO) and reduced graphene oxide (rGO) for comparison. The X-ray diffraction analysis of GO shows a peak in the range 2θ≈10˚ with 13.2 Å d-spacing (002 planes) related to the presence of oxygen-containing groups. By contrast, NPG, NSG and rGO had a single peak centered at 2θ ≈ 25˚, which is attributed to the presence of disordered layers of graphitic carbon from graphene (JCPDS 13-0148), which means that the GO was successfully converted to reduced graphene oxide in the NPG and NSG samples [41]. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm measurements were performed to determine the pore textural properties of the as-prepared doped-graphene. As shown in Fig. 2 a typical IV-type sorption isotherm curves with distinct characteristic hysteresis loops were observed in the rGO, NSG and NPG, indicating the existence of mesopores [42]. The pore-size distributions of NSG and NPG were ranged from 1 to 8 nm (Fig. 2b). The BET specific surface area of the rGO, NSG and NPG were 80, 229 and 100 m²g−1, respectively. The higher specific surface area of the dual-doped graphene samples, especially of the NSG, can be attributed to the decomposition of ammonium salts during carbonization, increasing the mesopore formation. The enhanced surface area implies a higher number of active sites and a much better diffusion of reactants and products. The morphologies of the dual-doped graphene samples were investigated by field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM). SEM images of NSG and NPG are displayed in Fig. 3 a and b, respectively, which show graphene sheets with a porous structure in both samples. The NSG shows thin wavy sheets that overlap randomly with each other. These types of sheets can easily form porous structures, which was confirmed by the BET analysis. The size of pores varies from sub-micrometer to several micrometers. The 3D porous lattice structure can accelerate the process of adsorption and diffusion of ions in the electrolyte, which eventually improves electrochemical performance. Wavy and transparent silk-like nanosheets of NSG can be observed from the TEM images in Fig. 3c. The edges of the graphitic network were well defined and represent a good crystallization of the NSG sample. It is clear from the image that N/S doped graphene layers were duplicated separately and a thin two-dimensional structure of graphene layers was preserved. Besides, the interconnected graphene layers had waves and grooves, which may be due to the shrinkage of graphene materials by heat treatment and doped heteroatoms. Many of the graphene layers were irregular, causing structural defects such as edges and cavities. These defects can improve the electrocatalytic activity by shortening the diffusion pathway [16,42,43]. To further investigate the surface elemental composition of samples, XPS measurements were carried out. As shown in Fig. 4 , the XPS survey spectra of NSG and NPG presented a dominant C 1s peak (284.8 eV), O 1s peak (∼532.9 and 530.6 eV), N 1s peak (∼398.4 and 399.7 eV), a S 2p peak (∼163.9 eV) and P 2p peak (∼133.8 eV), confirming successful S/N and P/N co-doping. Corresponding surface atomic percentages of the NSG and NPG are given in Fig. 4. The N 1s core level spectra of NSG and NPG (Fig. 5 a) can be decomposed into three contributions due to the presence of graphitic, pyridinic and pyrrolic nitrogen with percentages of 23, 52 and 25 % for sample NSG, and 18, 44 and 38 % for sample NPG, respectively [44]. The pathway for reduction of four electrons of O2 to H2O and the increase of the ORR-function depend on the nitrogen active sites. Previous reports and studies have shown that the performance of ORR can be related to the amount of pyridinic groups in the graphene structure [45–47]. The C 1s core level spectra for NSG and NPG are shown in Fig. 5b. The three contributions observed for NSG represent CC, C–S & CN, and CO bonds. The P 2p core level spectrum (Fig. 5c) shows the P 2p 3/2 contribution at 133.8 eV, which is typical of phosphate [48] The S 2p core level spectrum for NSG (Fig. 5d) shows the doublet S 2p 3/2 and S 2p 1/2 with a value of 163.3 eV for S 2p 3/2 typical of thiophenic sulfur [49]. The doping of S and P heteroatoms in a carbon network (C–S and COP covalent bond formation) can negatively displace carbon atoms that are adjacent to heteroatoms (S or P), while oxygen act as a bridge between carbon and phosphorous at PO bond, thus oxygen can increase deficiency of electrons in carbon atoms. These two structures can improve the number of electron transfer and, therefore, are suitable for improving ORR performance [50]. According to Fig. 4, the C 1s peak intensity of NSG was higher than of NPG, while the intensity of O 1s was much lower. Therefore, a lower amount of oxygen functional groups (such as CO, carbonyl or carboxylate) in NSG indicates a decrease in oxygen content and more carbonization [51]. The presence of CN and C–S bonds in NSG, as well as COP and CN bonds in NPG indicate successful N/S and N/P doped graphene. The Raman spectra of NSG, NPG and rGO are shown in Fig. 6 . All samples displayed two Raman bands at approximately 1345 and 1580 cm−1 assigned to D and G bands, respectively. The D band is a result of irregular and displaced carbon atoms and is due to the defect sites in the hexagonal framework of graphite materials, while the G band is due to the high degree of graphitization of carbon structure, which is suitable for electrical conductivity. The NPG also shows a Raman band at 2722 cm-1, which is assigned to a 2D-band. The ratio of D and G bands (ID/IG) is a good indicator of the disorder degree and graphitization of the graphene, since the height of the D peak usually increases upon chemical alteration of the carbon structure. The intensity ratio of ID/IG of the D and G bands for rGO, NSG and NPG were 0.98, 1.09 and 1.02, respectively, which indicate a higher disorder degree and defects of the graphene formed in the NSG and NPG catalysts. This suggests successful heteroatom doping of graphene, especially in the NSG catalyst. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) studies were carried out for NPG, NSG and rGO samples in a conventional three-electrode system to investigate the electrocatalytic activity toward ORR in alkaline media. Fig. 7 a shows the cyclic voltammograms obtained in O2-saturated 0.1 M NaOH aqueous solution from −0.1–1.2 V vs. RHE at room temperature. The rGO exhibited very poor ORR catalytic activity compared with the NPG and NSG samples, which display specific cathodic redox peaks at 0.75 and 0.76 V vs. RHE, respectively. This was attributed largely to the doping of graphene with heteroatoms. A rotating disk electrode (RDE) was used to further investigate electrocatalytic activity toward ORR. Linear sweep voltammogram (LSV) measurements were performed in O2-saturated 0.1 M NaOH solution at a scan rate of 0.005 V.s−1 and a rotation rate of 1600 rpm (Fig. 7b). The activity measured by the ORR onset in the LSV curves increased from 0.878 V vs. RHE for NSG, to 0.856 V vs. RHE for NPG (Table 1 ). Considering that our graphene materials are free of any metal, it should be noted that the gap between the onset potentials of NSG and the standard Pt/C is only 30 mV as the latter was found to have an onset potential of 0.908 V vs. RHE. Moreover, the LSV curve of NSG shows a well-defined diffusion-limiting current with a limiting current density of 4.85 mA cm-2 at 0.35 V vs. RHE. This value is again higher than that of NPG (3.86 mA cm-2). The E1/2 values can represent the capacity that a fuel cell cathode needs when holding a high working potential to deliver high energy conversion efficiency. From Table 1, it can be seen that the NSG sample had a higher E1/2 value than the NPG sample. These results are consistent with those of CV measurements also stand out as a clear indication of the beneficial role played by the N/S dual-doped graphene. Additional insight was gained into the ORR performances of the dual-doped graphenes through RDE voltammetry measurements. Fig. 7c and e show LSV curves of ORR at various rotation rates for NPG and NSG, respectively. To determine the kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction of the NSG and NPG, the Kouteckye-Levich (K–L) plot was analyzed. According to Fig. 7c, linear curves represent first-order kinetics for the process. Calculated from K–L Eqs. (1) and (2), the electron transfer number (n) was 2.73–3.1 for NPG and 3.31–3.33 for NSG at 0.45 to 0.6 V vs. RHE (Fig. 7d and f and Table 1), suggesting that the NSG is more inclined to reduce O2 via a dominated four-electron pathway. Further characterization of the ORR activity was made using Tafel plots at low overpotentials (Fig. 8 ). The Tafel slope of NSG (106 mV.dec−1) was smaller than that of NPG (125 mV.dec−1). Therefore, the kinetics towards ORR must be more favorable with the introduction of S atom than P atom on N-doped graphene, indicating the high catalytic activity of NSG in alkaline media. From the above results, the observed differences in the ORR activity may be due to a combination of factors. The secondary heteroatom, S and P, were incorporated on N-doped graphene in the form of thiophenic sulfur and phosphate, respectively. The heteroatoms not only affect the electronic structure of the neighbor carbon atoms, but also affect structural properties such as specific surface area, additional defects and exposed nitrogen species in the N-doped graphene obtained. The specific surface area of NSG is greater than of NPG, and the contents of nitrogen (5.06 wt%) and sulfur (1.67 wt%) in NSG are superior to those of NPG (N: 4.5 wt% and P: 0.95 wt %). In this context, the higher BET specific surface area of NSG compared to NPG, can also be explained by the formation of C–S bonds versus COP bonds. These bond modifications cause structural distortion and differences in bond length and bond angles. A summary of different dual-doped graphene catalysts discussed so far and their properties and ORR activity values presented in Table 2 . From the table, metal-free dual-doped graphene has evolved as a promising catalyst system to replace the traditional Pt-black catalyst system for ORR. Nitrogen atoms active oxygen molecules, directly or indirectly, through carbon bonding. According to previous studies, the electrocatalytic activity of N-containing metal-free graphene is highly dependent on the N-graphitic content while N-pyridinic species improve the onset potential for ORR [54]. N-pyridinic species with high electron receiving can create a positive charge on adjacent carbon atoms, thereby improving O2-absorption and facilitating the adsorption of electrons from the anode, which ultimately improves ORR activity. However, some researchers have also shown that N-graphitic contributes to catalytic activity by reducing absorption energy [55,56]. N-graphitic species have been reported to determine limiting current density, whereas N-pyridinic species convert the reaction mechanism from 2e− to 4e− pathway, which improves the onset potential of catalysts [54]. Therefore, both N-(pyridinic and graphitic) groups improve electrocatalytic properties by creating different roles [11,52]. Our results show that the contents of N-graphitic and N-pyridinic groups at NSG (75.4 %) are higher than those at NPG (62 %), and are greater than the N-pyridinic species in NSG. Fig. 9 illustrates the relationship between N-species concentration of N-pyridinic and N-graphitic (at. %) evaluated by XPS and the onset potential of NPG and NSG catalysts, indicating that with a higher N-pyridinic concentration, a higher onset potential is obtained. Therefore, secondary heteroatom has a great impact on the type of N sites obtained and ORR activities. In the N, S- dual-doped graphene, S atoms promote the creation of higher N-pyridinic species in the graphene layer and consequently a greater ORR activity. It is known that a P-doped graphene structure increases ORR activity in alkaline media by breaking and changing the bond length and electroneutrality of the carbon structure simultaneously [39]. N and P have similar valence electrons thus they have similar chemical properties. N atoms can easily enter into the carbon network and create high-stability CN covalent bonds due to their similar radius to carbon atoms. On the other hand, P has a more electron absorption capacity than N, but due to the difference in atomic size between P and C, the value of P is lower than N [57,58]. Due to the higher atomic radius of phosphorus compare to nitrogen and carbon, phosphorus atoms protrude from the surrounding atoms [31]. This excretion of phosphorus atoms facilitates interaction and contact with oxygen, which can improve ORR activity. On the other site, S atoms cause structural defects at the carbon network that lead to the formation of active edge locations. These places make it easy to concentrate and absorb O2. Also, lone S pairs can interact with surrounding oxygen molecules, which is beneficial for ORR electrocatalytic activity. An increase of spin density has been found in N/S co-doped graphene. Charge density and asymmetric spin cause a large number of active sites, so the synergistic effect of heteroatoms improves the ORR activity [52]. According to theoretical studies, S absorbed at the base planes of graphene exhibits limited ORR activity, while S with covalent bond is easily oxidized at the edges of graphene and forms a charge density distribution in graphene structure, leading to a polarized region that increase catalytic activity toward ORR [20]. Also, theoretical calculations show that the doping of heteroatoms such as phosphorus and sulfur reduce the band gap energy (between HUMO and LUMO) in graphene, so co-doping of N/P and N/S can lead to an acceptable reduction in distance. The energy gap of graphene is one of the most significant reasons for increasing and improving of ORR activity [59]. 4 Conclusions Metal-free N/S and N/P dual-doped reduced graphene oxide electrocatalysts were successfully synthesized through using a simple one-step thermal annealing method by directly pyrolyzing a homogenous mixture of graphene oxide (GO) and (NH4)2SO4 or (NH4)2HPO4, respectively. The structural and surface chemical properties were investigated and the results indicated the effective incorporation of sulfur and phosphorus into N-doped graphene structures. S can be doped in the form of thiophenic S and P can be doped in the form of phosphate. The secondary heteroatom considerably affects the specific surface area and the contents of graphitic N and pyridinic N species in the N-doped graphene, which are higher in the N,S dual-doped graphene (NSG) catalyst. The results imply that NSG has the appropriate structure and surface active centers, thus leading to the best ORR performance in alkaline media. coredata.dc:description: Heteroatomic dual-doped metal free graphene materials have revealed significant improvement in the electrocatalysis properties for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in alkaline anion exchange membrane fuel cells. Here we report a straightforward and cost-effective strategy to fabricate N, S- and N, P- dual-doped reduced graphene oxide electrocatalysts, characterized by similar N/S and N/P ratios. For this purpose, we used ammonium sulfate ((NH4)2SO4) and ammonium monohydrogenphosphate ((NH4)2HPO4) as heteroatom precursors to obtain the desired catalysts by pyrolysis with graphene oxide. Systematic characterization reveals that the secondary heteroatom S has a greater promotional effect than P in ORR. Furthermore, the gap between the onset potentials of N, S- dual-doped graphene and the standard Pt/C is only 30 mV. The results imply that the combination of the N, S heteroatoms and the surface structure in dual-doped reduced graphene oxide lead to a synergistic effect in catalyzing ORR in alkaline media.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of secondary heteroatom (S, P) in N-doped reduced graphene oxide catalysts to oxygen reduction reaction
